messageBody:
Hi Cédric,

> FYI, a few more reactions and articles on the same topic. It looks like
> most of the Java and Ruby communities (last link) are typically using a
> small portion of TDD and a majority of regular testing, which matches my
> experience.

I don't think anyone ever disagreed that "regular testing" interpreted
to mean automated acceptance testing and unit testing is not done to
the extent we would like to see on this list. I don't think anyone
needs to be convinced about this, this is a known fact, one that a lot
of us believe should change. It is in the conclusions that can be
derived from that where opinions differ. You seem to say that since
most software is not "regularly tested" and most software works great
you can abviously do perfectly well without "regular testing".

Myself and others have argued that most software can work better and
that our acceptance for errors is too high. David Saff also made an
interesting comment about all the software we don't see, the software
we don't use and the software that is never released. I think it is
natural that popular software used by many works great, or it
wouldn''t be popular. Popular software can also deferr some testing to
their "beta"-testers and "get away with it". But that is just a small
fraction of all the software written.

I personally think that you are way wrong that there is code that is
ot tested and works. I think that all software out there is tested,
meaning some effort has been made to ensure that it works. There are
hard ways and easy ways to test software. The easy way (I think it is
automated testing) is the most reliable while the hard way requires
some guesswork and predictions coupled with manual effort.

I followed the first link and got a little bit upset by one of your
transcriptions of a supposedly rethorical answer:

"One response to the question suggests that there are only two types
of code: Code that is tested and works and code that is not tested and
doesn't work. Cedric's take on the subject is that there are ways of
knowing that your code is working without actually testing it. So we
should also include a third category: Code that is not tested and
works."

That was your subjective interpretation of what Robert C Martin wrote.
When you asked for clarification you asked:

"You seem to imply that there are only two kinds of code:

- Code that is tested and works
- Code that is not tested and doesn't work

There is actually something in the middle: it's called "Code that
is not
tested but that works"."

That was the interpretation you used in the blog-entry.
The reply came:

"The two kinds of code are:

- Code you have tested, and you know works to the best of your
ability to determine.
- Code you have not tested and don't know if it works.

If you haven't tested the code, you don't know that it works. If you
HAVE tested the code then you know that it passes your tests."


Why didn't you just post the statement as it was written instead of
your subjective interpretation? Your interpretation sure has more
punch that the real thing but it is obviously not what the author
meant.

I really admire you taking a stand in this discussion and in this
forum. A lot of really good discussion has come out of it and not many
are so brave as you are to go against the flow on a board like this.
But when you post subjective interpretaions like the one above you
loose credibility, atleast with me. And I think that is a shame
because you obviously have a message that you want to get through
with. I think your opinions deserves to be listened to and evaluated.

I didn't read the rest of the links or the comments, perhaps something
more interesting or would have com up there.

Just one mans opinion
/J
